--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, David Saff <saff@m...> wrote:
> ...
> I reall=
y like assertThat.  I've reimplemented it at least twice to take 
> advanta=
ge of
> generics:
> 
> public void <T> assertThat (T obj, Constraint<T> con=
straint);
> 
> That said, it's a little heavy-weight if you want to define =
many new 
> constraints, and I still need to find the right balance.
> ...
=

You're right, generics make sense here; I posted my generified version
in =
the forum mentioned before
(http://saloon.javaranch.com/cgi-bin/ubb/ultimat=
ebb.cgi?ubb=3Dget_topic&f=3D68&t=3D000944).

Why do you think that this apr=
oach is heavy weight? What would be less
heavy weight?


--- In junit@yahoo=
groups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@r...> wrote:
> ...
> I would prefe=
r @BeforeTest, @BeforeSuite and their @After* companions.
> ...

I agree, i=
t reads better and is more exact in its meaning. What do the
other readers =
(especially those who haven't responded yet) think about
using these names?=



While browsing through the latest source code of JUnit two more
question=
s turned up in my head:
1) Why does junit.framework.Assert still define ass=
ertEquals for
boolean, int, long etc. (autoboxing could do that; in fact, d=
eleting
those methods doesn't produce any errors)?
2) Why isn't java.lang.A=
ssertionError used instead of
junit.framework.AssertionFailedError?

Thanks=
 for your patience,
Michael Herrmann
